passages.text: This material is neither intended to be distributed to Mainland China investors nor to provide securities investment consultancy services within the territory of Mainland China. This material or any portion hereof may not be reprinted, sold or redistributed without the written consent of J.P. Morgan.
In case you missed it, Asia's Most Read Publications: 19 Aug to 25 Aug 2025
Asia chemicals (Parsley Rui Hua Ong)

Select Asian chemical stocks have rallied \(3 - 27\%\) over the past two days (MSCI Asia - \(1\%\) ) due to: (1) Korea's MOTIE coordinating a voluntary 3.7MtpA NCC shutdown across 10 companies, representing \(25\%\) of Korea's 13MtpA total (Yonhap news); and (2) news that the Chinese government might roll out a detailed plan to phase out old/outdated chemical capacities in September. We believe the Chinese and Korean governments' chemical rationalization efforts target the right goals, and while the impact on core earnings might take time to materialize, the direction is clear and might help the sector recover gradually over the next two years. We recommend buying higher- quality chemical names like LG Chem, Kumho, Hengli and PetroChina (all rated OW), while potentially revisiting lower- quality chemical names if more sustainable rationalization measures take root.
Reliance Industries Ltd (Sanjay Mookim) (RELIANCE IN, OW, PT Rs1,695.00)

RIL's relative valuations appear reasonable to us despite its YTD outperformance. The implied holding company discount available on Jio/Retail (measured at Bharti/DMART EV/EBITDA) remains elevated, as these stocks have also done well. Better O2C margins, potential tariff increases and improved retail growth could help. OW.
Global Power Equipment (Stephen Tsui, CFA/Mark Strouse, CFA/Junya Ayada)

Rising global transmission capex has led to strong demand for high voltage equipment. This, coupled with limited capacity expansion has resulted in meaningful price hikes, increase in margin and earnings revisions for relevant equipment makers, and hence strong share performance (Figure 5). Apart from transformers and switchgears, we believe the tight supply of HVDC equipment is another key bottleneck in the ongoing energy transition. HVDC systems allow the efficient transmission of large amounts of power across long distances, which is essential to renewable development and cross- border electricity interconnection. While demand is surging globally, the Western market is dominated by three players (Hitachi, GE Vernova, Siemens Energy) and supply of key components is tight ( \(\sim 10\) years of lead time for converter valves). Looking ahead, we believe Asian players have the potential to gain market share, given their plans for capacity expansion and development of local technology. Key names we would highlight are LS Electric, Hyosung Heavy, Nari Tech and Xuji.
Digitizing India Series (Ankur Rudra, CFA)
Mirror, Mirror on the Wall... #6: Screening for Pricing & Availability - subsidies rising again in 2Q26

Eternal has outperformed the NIFTY by \(\sim 12\%\) YTD (see Figure 1) on the back of strong 1QFY26 results and expectations of moderating competitive intensity, while Swiggy continues to lag the NIFTY by \(\sim 29\%\) YTD, on concerns of persistent QC burn. We maintain our Quick Commerce (QC) channel checks to price & availability on a basket of 65 SKUs (8 categories) in 50 pincodes across the industry to assess the risk from subsidies and deduce relative competitive positions. Our prior checks (MMOW Vol 2, MMOW Vol 3, MMOW Vol 4, & MMOW Vol 5) enumerate data since Feb 2025. We present these in 50 charts and tables but can share a lot more insights for investors interested in looking at deeper SKU/category/city wide trends.
Mazagon Dock Shipbuilders Ltd (Atul Tiwari) (MAZDOCKS IN, UW, PT Rs2,468.00)

We reiterate our UW rating on MDL as the risk- reward remains adverse despite the stock price correction. 4QFY25 and 1QFY26 results were very weak due to provisioning related to cost overruns. More importantly, the large order award for P- 75 Scorpene submarines (3 Nos) is yet to materialize and has been delayed versus earlier guidance. If these awards get delayed further, it would pose a risk to FY28 revenue estimates given it takes \(\sim 2\) years for revenue to start being recognized. As of now, there appears to be little incremental positive news flow on the P- 75I (6 Nos) submarine award either. We think all of these negative factors will weigh on stock price performance in addition to existing concerns about the underlying margin structure. Longer- term, margins (as seen over the past few years) may not be sustainable, posing risks to medium- term earnings growth. Reiterate UW with reduced PT of Rs2468 (from Rs3027). We cut our FY26E/FY27E/FY28E EPS by \(8\% /11\% /12\%\) .

Pop Mart to be added to HSI and HSCEI. According to the Hang Seng Index Review Results on Aug 22, Pop Mart will be one of the three stocks to be included in the Hang Seng Index and the stock will also be included in the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index. All changes will be implemented after market close on 5 September 2025 (Friday) and take effect on 8 September 2025 (Monday). See source.

In the last week, the market has started to worry again about whether Al capex growth is likely to peak out in 2026, given elevated capex and some concerns resurfacing over (1) a lack of ROI from Al deployments and (2) the ability of companies to keep funding Al capex. Coupled with the lack of near- term upside from NVDA/AMD's GPU shipments into China, we believe that investors are starting to take a more guarded approach on Al stocks in the near term. Our view is different: (1) We do not see any signs of excesses in the Al trade, the top 4 CSPs are still funding capex from their growing operating cashflows, and have ample ability to keep driving a growing capex budget well into 2027; (2) Large Private Al Labs and sovereigns are also joining the fray to keep driving Al investments (2) Al use- cases have proliferated substantially, especially in consumer Al (not so much inenterprise Al so far), with reasoning models adoption still at a fairly early stage (only 6 months in, since Deepseek R1 launch), resulting in very strong growth in token consumption. (4) China's capex growth has not even started in earnest, presenting another vector for demand growth. We believe that Al capex is poised to grow at least \(\sim 20\%\) in 2026, with the potential for further growth into 2027, as reasoning model adoption continues to grow and early signs of enterprise/ agentic Al workloads emerge through 2026- 27. Within Al, we continue to stay positive on core Al leaders (TSMC, SK Hynix, Hon Hai, Delta), while also seeing some new opportunities in substrates, OSAT (ASE), and in China Al buildout. Into 2026, the GOOG TPU foodchain appears poised for the strongest growth, followed by NVDA, AMD and AWS. Beyond Al, we are starting to see broader discussions on price hikes (BT substrates, T- Glass, some elements of ABF substrates, power management, legacy DRAM, high end OSAT etc), which may drive the next leg of tech EPS revisions.
EM Money Trail (Rajiv Batra/Emy Shayo Cherman)

EM equity funds turned positive this week with \(+\) 2.0bn of inflows, following two weeks of sell- off. The recovery was entirely due ETFs that drew \(+\) 2.9bn of net subscriptions while non- ETFs continued to see outflows (- \(880mn, -\) 1.5bn last week). All regional funds were positive this week. Asia ex- Japan was in the lead with inflows of \(+\) 1.6bn (- \(499mn last week) while EMEA funds saw inflows of \(+\) 188mn - the largest in five months. LatAm saw small inflows (+\) 13mn) after five weeks of redemptions. Regional GEMs funds saw small inflows of \(+\) 158mn after two weeks of sell- off. EM ex- China posted redemptions (- \(80mn). YTD EM equity fund flows are -\) 5.5bn (ETFs: \(+\) 38.8bn, non- ETFs: - \(44.3bn); incorporating July monthly data led to a revision of -\) 4.0bn.
Press Metal (Benny Kurniawan, CFA) (PMAH MK, OW, PT RM5.90)

Our First Take: PMAH reported in- line 2Q25 results. 2Q25 NPATMI stood at RM483.6mn, down \(4\%\) y/y but up \(5\%\) q/q. 1H25 NPATMI stood at RM945.3mn, up \(3\%\) y/y and accounting for \(50 / 49\%\) of JPM/Consensus FY25E. Key discussion points in this quarter's results were 1) realization of higher priced alumina inventory in 2Q hampered margin gains in the smelting business; 2) lower alumina prices significantly reduced associate contribution from Nanshan (associates down \(45\%\) q/q and \(17\%\) y/y), while Nanshan has completed its \(3^{\mathrm{rd}}\) 1mtpa capacity expansion and 3) PMAH's smelting volume is back to optimum levels of \(- 97\%\) utilization rate. While we believe the results are relatively in line with expectations, the 2H outlook for the business remains bright. We believe smelting EBIT margins will sequentially improve driven by 1) realization of lower alumina priced inventory; 2) slight sequential improvement in carbon anode prices and 3) better all- in aluminum prices that have been observable QTD (QTD LME aluminum at USD2,600/t vs 2Q25 average of USD2454/t). PMAH has also over provisioned for taxes in 1H25 with regards to GMT (global minimum taxes) and is guiding for \(- 11\%\) tax rate in 2H25 (vs \(12\%\) in 1H25). We remain positive on PMAH and see better earnings delivery in 2H25 driving the share price higher.
TSMC (Gokul Hariharan) (2330 TT, OW, PT NT\$1275.0)

There have been significant developments around Intel in the last two weeks, with the US government indicating that it is looking to take a stake in the company (in exchange for CHIPS Act grants already agreed upon), Softbank taking a \(\) 2bn\(stake, and commentary surrounding key fabless customers likely to participate in an Intel Foundry rescue (likely through investments and potential product commitments at Intel Foundry). US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick has also indicated that the US cannot rely on TSMC and Taiwan for all its advanced chip supply and would like to have more capacity reshored back to the US in the future. The initial read for TSMC from these events has been seen as negative, given the concerns about Intel Foundry's emergence as a competitor. We take a more nuanced view:
